Question: There are many doubts, please resolve them. Therefore, the Prajnaparamita Sutra says: 'If one sees me in form,
or seeks me in sound, this person is on the wrong path and cannot see the Tathagata.
' Why then, is it that by mindfulness of Amitabha Buddha and rebirth in the Pure Land, one can see the Tathagata?

Answer:ğŸ”½The Prajnaparamita Sutra's prohibition against seeing the Tathagata is because if one seeks the person and self in the single appearance and sound, one does not seek rebirth and supreme enlightenment, and thus only practices the wrong path and does not see the Tathagata.

The Sutra on Contemplation of the Buddha, the Sutra on Amitabha, and other sutras should give rise to thoughts and exclusively chant the name, not seeking the person and self, but only seeking to be reborn in the Pure Land and quickly realize supreme enlightenment, which is called the right path and seeing the Tathagata.
If we consider the Dharma body, the signless is correct, while form, appearance, and sound are considered deviant. This is for bodhisattvas at the tenth ground and above;

The Contemplation Sutra and the Amitabha Sutra state that contemplating a single mark or hearing the name leads to seeing the reward body of the Tathagata. This is for ordinary beings, the two vehicles, and small bodhisattvas.
If we consider the reward body, contemplating the Buddha and chanting his name are considered correct, while the signless is deviant;
If we consider the Dharma body, all is said to be signless.

Moreover, when the Prajnaparamita Sutra was being spoken, the World Honored One first went to the Heaven of the Thirty-three to speak Dharma for his mother. At that time, the World Honored One had just come down from the heavens to Jambudvipa. Subhuti remembered the World Honored One and entered concentration to contemplate the Buddha. He thus came first.
At that time, there was a goddess who did not know the reason. She saw the World Honored One first. Having seen the Buddha, the goddess then asked the Buddha, saying:
Did I see the Buddha first or not?
The World-Honored One said:
You will see later.
The goddess said:
I just arrived, and no one has come to see the Buddha yet. Why is it later?
The World-Honored One said:
There is SubhÅ«ti who entered concentration first, removed the self and others, and saw the Dharma body before the goddess, so he saw it first.
The goddess, because she gave rise to the mind of self and others and observed her physical body, saw it later.
The World-Honored One, in response to that goddess, spoke a verse, saying:
If one sees me with form, or seeks me with sound, this person walks the wrong path and cannot see the TathÄgata.
This verse immediately responds to the non-Buddhists to benefit the present time, without offending matters in future generations, unlike the Contemplation Sutra.

Moreover, the Prajnaparamita was taught to refute the non-Buddhists' view that the four elements and five aggregates are permanent, and their view that form is the self, and that sound is the self. Therefore, the Prajnaparamita Sutra refutes those non-Buddhists and shows that they do not see the Tathagata;

Now, based on the Guanjing and other sutras, the teaching of the door of disgust and aversion is taught, vowing to leave birth and death, be quickly reborn in the Pure Land, and quickly realize enlightenment. Not contemplating the characteristics of the self, one finally sees the Tathagata, which is different from the Prajnaparamita.
Question:
The Treatise on Rebirth says:
Women, those with incomplete faculties, and those of the two vehicles will not be reborn.
Why does the Guanjing say that Vaidehi and her five hundred attendants will be reborn together?
In the middle grade, three people of the two vehicles are reborn?

According to the Treatise on Rebirth, women and those of the two vehicles who are not reborn there are those who do not have the nature of definitely being reborn there.
Women only love their female bodies and do not seek the Pure Land. They are unwilling to recite the Buddha's name and discuss the obstacles to rebirth.

The two vehicles and those with incomplete faculties are also like this. They only abide in the small fruits and do not take rebirth in the Pure Land. They do not understand reciting the Buddha's name, so they do not take rebirth.

The Guanjing and the Amituo Jing and other sutras speak of those who take rebirth, including those of the two vehicles, those with incomplete faculties, and women, who turn their minds to reciting the Buddha's name and detest their female bodies.

Reciting the Buddha's name against the three levels of teachings. Question:
In the three levels of teachings, one does not sit on the monks' seats or eat the monks' food.
In the Buddha-mindfulness practice, I do not yet know if it is allowed to eat the monks' food, sit on the monks' seats, and pass the meal time.
The answer:
In the Buddha-mindfulness practice, it is generally allowed to eat the monks' food, sit on the monks' seats, and pass the meal time.
Why is it so?
Because those who practice Buddha-mindfulness are like the king, or like the prince, worthy of receiving the king's salary, worthy of receiving the TathÄgata's support;

Moreover, the Buddha is like parents, and those who practice Buddha-mindfulness are like children, who should be given food, clothing, beds, and bedding by their parents, so it is allowed to sit on the monks' seats, eat the monks' food, and pass the meal time.
Objection:
Those who do not sit on the monks' seats and do not eat the monks' food are practitioners, and those of the lowest class are also practitioners.
Why is it so?

Because those of the lowest class do not sit on the monks' seats and do not eat the monks' food, and since those of the lowest class are not practitioners, these three levels are also not practitioners.
Question:
The three levels are called evil sentient beings, and those who contemplate the Buddha are good sentient beings. Are they also evil sentient beings?
Answer:
They are not evil sentient beings.
How do we know?
According to a sutra, it says:
'If one contemplates the Buddha, one is a lotus flower among humans.'
This flower is the best among all flowers;
if one contemplates the Buddha, one is the best among all people, so it is used as a metaphor.
Because it eliminates all offenses, it is a good sentient being;
the three levels do not eliminate offenses, so they are evil sentient beings.
Objection:
Evil sentient beings are those who cultivate the path. Sick people should be cultivating the path.
Why is it so?
Because they are evil sentient beings. Those sick people are not cultivating the path, and these three levels are also not cultivating the path.
Question:
The Three Levels Dharma does not allow entering temples, but does the Buddha-recitation Dharma allow entering temples?
Answer:
In the Buddha-recitation Dharma, it allows residing in temples and observing.
Why is it so?

Because in the present, one resides in a good place, and in the future, one intends to be born in a good country and attain enlightenment. Therefore, it allows residing in temples and entering the good places of monastic compounds.
Objection:
Monastic compounds and good places are not allowed for inferior sentient beings to reside in;
The unsurpassed, supreme, and wonderful fruits cannot be attained by inferior sentient beings.
Question:
In the Three Levels Dharma, seeing Buddha images and scriptures, one does not pay much respect, considering them to be clay statues;
Because the four types of sentient beings are the true Buddha, one pays respect to them.
In the Buddha-recitation Dharma, I do not know whether one should respect Buddha images and scriptures.
Answer:
The Buddha-recitation Dharma says:
'Seeing Buddha images and scriptures, one should pay respect to them all.
Why is this so?
According to what is said in the Sutra of Repaying Kindness:
Shakyamuni Buddha went to the Heaven of the Thirty-three Celestials to expound the Dharma for his mother, Queen Maya, for ninety days.
King Udayana missed the World-Honored One and could not see him, so he had a skilled craftsman create a statue of the World-Honored One, exactly like the World-Honored One.

When the World-Honored One descended from the heavens and returned to Jambudvipa, King Udayana and his ministers went to welcome the Buddha, and the statue of the Buddha also went to welcome the World-Honored One.
The World-Honored One and the statue of the Buddha stood side by side, the two Buddhas being similar in appearance, so he placed his hand on the head of the statue of the Buddha and said:
I will soon enter nirvana, leaving you to remain in the world for a long time to teach and transform sentient beings.
The World-Honored One himself still revered the Buddha's statue, so how could sinful beings not revere it?
Moreover, according to the Sutra of the Ten Wheels, it says:
'The hunter wore the kasaya, and the elephant rose to show respect.
Respecting the merits of the kasaya, after death he was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three, enjoying bliss for ninety-one kalpas.'
Why is this?
Because it is similar.
The Buddha's images are also like this. Because they are similar, those who respect them will attain nobility, glory, and rebirth in the heavens and pure lands.
Therefore, in the Buddha-name sutra, there is the Buddha Vairocana who respects the Buddha's images.
Since the Buddha Vairocana himself respects the Buddha's images, how could ordinary people not respect them?
Moreover, the Huayan Sutra says:
'The samadhi of mindfulness of the Buddha will enable one to see the Buddha. After death, one will be reborn in the presence of the Buddha.'

When that person is about to die, they are encouraged to be mindful of the Buddha and shown the Buddha's image to be looked up to and respected. Therefore, it is known that the Huayan Sutra includes the instruction to respect the Buddha's images. How can the Three Levels of Difficulty say:
'All images are clay statues, and food offered to them should not be eaten;
all cows and donkeys are real Buddhas, and food offered to them should be eaten.
All images are clay statues, and offerings of clothing should not be worn.
All sentient beings are real Buddhas, and if one obtains clothing from insects, how can one wear it?
All sentient beings are real Buddhas, and one should not harm them. Within a year, the number of lives harmed is countless. How can the sin of killing the Buddha be removed?

All sentient beings are real Buddhas, and one's body should be placed in a superior and wonderful place. If one's own body is in a good house, and the Buddha is in a bad place, how can it be considered equal?'

Reciting the Buddha's name is the One Vehicle, but the Three Levels is not the One Vehicle.
Why is it so?
If it were the One Level, it could be the One Vehicle;
Since it speaks of the Three Levels, how can it constitute the meaning of the One Vehicle?

The second gate of chanting the Buddha's name in relation to Maitreya. Question:
How does chanting the merits of Amitabha Buddha compare to chanting Maitreya?
Answer:
Chanting the merits of Amitabha Buddha is a hundred thousand times more than chanting Maitreya.
How do we know this?
According to the sutra, Amitabha Buddha is now fully enlightened and has completed the fruit, surpassing all stages. Those who chant his name have the most merit;
Maitreya is now in the bodhisattva stage, has not yet surpassed the stages, and has not yet completed the fruit. Therefore, those who chant his name have less merit.

Question:
When Maitreya descends to be born in the future, he will expound the Dharma at the three assemblies, deliver sentient beings, and enable them to attain the fruit of arhatship.

Billions of sentient beings do not encounter Maitreya Buddha.

Moreover, when the original teacher spoke the Sutra of Amitabha Buddha, Maitreya Bodhisattva was also in the assembly, the bodhisattva Adhi-Mujita.

Moreover, according to the Buddha's teachings, in the Dharma-ending age, all practices will be completely extinguished, but this practice of mindfulness of the Buddha will remain for a hundred years to teach and transform sentient beings.
Therefore, we know that the mindfulness of the Buddha is inconceivable.
The Third Gate: Mindfulness of the Buddha Compared to Sitting in Meditation, Question:
How does mindfulness of Amitabha Buddha compare to sitting in meditation, contemplating the mind, and practicing the contemplation of non-arising?
Answer:
Mindfulness of Amitabha Buddha and rebirth in the Pure Land leads to the attainment of Buddhahood more quickly than the contemplation of non-arising by a hundred thousand million times.

' The contemplation of non-arising and observing the mind is also like this.
Why is it so?
Because non-arising is the same as signlessness, and signlessness is the same as empty space, it is difficult to accomplish;
The method of mindfulness of the Buddha, practicing both phenomena and principle, is like building a palace on the ground, which is easily accomplished.
If a poor person lacks wealth and treasures, and learns to build a house like the king's palace, although they may obtain a few materials, they will not be able to complete it from birth to death.
Later, the materials will rot and decay, wasting effort without any accomplishment.

The method of mindfulness of the Buddha is not like this. By reciting the Buddha's name once, eighty koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas of birth and death are eliminated, and eighty koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas of subtle merits are obtained.
It is like a wealthy child building a house and immediately accomplishing it.
Therefore, the Guanjing says:
However, because of the power of that TathÄgata's past vows, those who recollect him will definitely attain accomplishment.
It is not the same as non-arising.
Why is it so?

Not manifesting refers to non-arising. Since he could not attain Buddhahood for ten kalpas, we know that attaining Buddhahood is slow.

If one contemplates the mind, attaining Buddhahood is slow, then it takes seven days, and if it is fast, it takes one day. Quickly being reborn in the Pure Land is the same as being a bodhisattva at the eighth ground and above.

Question:
How does the merit of contemplating the mind compare to the merit of contemplating the Buddha?
Answer:
The merit of contemplating the mind is less than the merit of contemplating the Buddha by a hundred thousand myriads of times.
How do we know this?
According to the Guanjing:
Contemplating the Buddha once destroys the sins of birth and death accumulated over eighty koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas.
One attains the subtle merits accumulated over eighty koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas.
If one looks at the mind once, one does not know how much sin is extinguished or how much merit is obtained.
It does not say how many hundreds of millions of sins of birth and death are extinguished, or that all hells are extinguished and one is reborn in the Pure Land.
Therefore, know that the merit of a little mindfulness of the Buddha is a hundred thousand times greater.
Question:
What fruits and rewards does one obtain by being reborn through mindfulness of the Buddha?
What fruits and rewards does one obtain by perfecting the contemplation of non-arising?
Which of the two is superior?
Answer:

Being reborn through mindfulness of the Buddha, one obtains the thirty-two marks, the six spiritual powers, long life without death, transcending the three realms, going straight to Buddhahood, never falling back again, with the holy assembly of bodhisattvas as companions, and AmitÄbha Buddha personally expounding the Dharma;
By perfecting the contemplation of non-arising, one is reborn in the long-lived heavens and falls back into evil paths after eighty thousand great kalpas.
Of the contemplation of non-arising, not one in ten thousand achieves it, because it is not timely.
Even if one achieves it, one is reborn in the long-lived heavens and does not transcend the three realms.
If we compare the two, the Pure Land is a hundred thousand times better.

That sutra says:

in the Dharma-ending age of ten thousand years, mindfulness of the Buddha will be firm.

More than two hundred years have passed since the entry into the Dharma-ending age, this is the time for mindfulness of the Buddha, not the time for sitting meditation.
Therefore, during the lifetime of Great Practice Chan Master, many disciples of Chan masters, after being instructed by the Chan master, turned their minds to mindfulness of the Buddha.
The fourth section on mindfulness of the Buddha in contrast to lecturing on sutras. Question:
How does the merit of mindfulness of Amitabha Buddha compare to the merit of listening to sutras?
Answer:
The merit of mindfulness of the Buddha is a hundred thousand times greater than the merit of listening to sutras.
How can this be known?

The lowest grade of rebirth in the upper level in the Guanjing Sutra refers to people who have committed all kinds of evil deeds. Due to their evil actions, when their lives are about to end, the fires of hell all come at once.

The power of hearing the sutra is small, and the hells have not yet been extinguished. They obtain the teachings of the wise and remember Amitabha Buddha ten times, eliminating the sins of birth and death for eighty koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas.
Question:
How much is the merit of reading sutras compared to the merit of chanting the Buddha's name?
Answer:
The merit of reading sutras is also less than the merit of chanting the Buddha's name.
Great Master Xing said:
Not chanting the Buddha's name but practicing and reading sutras is like reading a medical prescription, while chanting the Buddha's name is like taking medicine.
Reading a medical prescription does not easily cure the illness;
taking medicine quickly alleviates the illness.

The merit of reading sutras and cultivating the Way is also less than the merit of mindfulness of the Buddha. This is precisely the cultivation of the Way, and therefore the merit is the most abundant.
Question:
How much is the merit of expounding the sutras compared to the merit of mindfulness of the Buddha?
Answer:
The merit of expounding the sutras is also less than the merit of mindfulness of the Buddha by a hundred thousand myriads of times.
Why is this so?

Expounding the sutras is like counting treasures, while mindfulness of the Buddha is like using treasures. Although counting treasures may be abundant, it does not eliminate poverty and suffering, and does not speak of extinguishing offenses or attaining merit;
Using treasures, although not much, can save one's life and attain immeasurable merit. It is clear that it is less than the merit of mindfulness of the Buddha by a hundred thousand myriads of times.

Moreover, expounding the sutras is like polishing a stone. Although one may obtain a little benefit, it is all given to others, and one's own loss is immeasurable. Receiving prostrations and offerings is a great loss of karmic retribution.
Therefore, the treatise says:
It is like a poor person who counts others' treasures day and night, but has not a penny of their own. The same is true of those with much learning.
Therefore, know that the merit of expounding the sutras is also far less than the merit of mindfulness of the Buddha by a hundred thousand myriads of times.

Arrogant, self-important, and deceitful, their minds are not genuine. For myriads of koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas, they do not hear the name of the Buddha, nor do they hear the true Dharma. Such people are difficult to save.

Chapter 11: The Gate of Reciting the Buddha's Name to Leave the Three Realms, Question:
Is the Pure Land outside the Three Realms or within the Three Realms?
Answer:
The Pure Land is definitely outside the Three Realms, not within the Three Realms.
Since it is said to be the Three Realms, what are the three?
First, the desire realm, from this JambudvÄ«pa up to the sixth heaven, is collectively called the desire realm;
Second, the form realm, above the six heavens, the Brahma-host Heaven and so forth, eighteen heavens, are called the form realm;
Third, the formless realm, which also has four heavens, from the sphere of infinite space up to the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception, collectively called the formless realm.

Moreover, above the twenty-eight heavens of the three realms, up to the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception, and below, it is the uninterrupted hell. People dwell in between, just like in a prison.
Therefore, the Lotus Sutra says:
The three realms are not at peace, like a burning house.
There are always the fires of birth, old age, sickness, death, and worries, burning without cease.
Therefore, VaidehÄ« detests the Saha world, a place of the five turbidities and evil.
What are the five?
First, the turbidity of the eon, referring to the eons of pestilence, famine, and warfare;
second, the turbidity of afflictions, as all beings have many afflictions;
third, the turbidity of lifespan, as lifespans are short;
fourth, the turbidity of views, as one slanders and lacks faith;
Fifth, the defilement of sentient beings, lacking human conduct, and filled with hells, hungry ghosts, and animals, gathering unwholesomeness.
Therefore, it sends one to be disgusted and delights in the Western Land of Ultimate Bliss.
The reason the sÅ«tra says:

Able to strive to liberate sentient beings from the prison of the three realms, the honored one of universal wisdom and humans, out of compassion for the multitude of blind beings, is able to open the gate of ambrosia and widely deliver all.
The treatise also says:
Surpassing the prison of the three realms, eyes like blue lotus leaves, countless assemblies of Å›rÄvakas, therefore I bow my head in reverence.
The Treatise on Rebirth also says:
Contemplating the characteristics of that world, surpassing the paths of the three realms, ultimate like empty space, vast and boundless.
Also, according to the Treatise on Resolving Doubts, it says:

The Pure Land is vertically transcendent to the three realms and horizontally cuts off the five paths. Once one attains rebirth, they will never again fall into the prison of the three realms, but will go straight to supreme enlightenment.

Therefore, we know that AmitÃ¢bha's Pure Land is definitely beyond the three realms and is not within the three realms. This is why the practice of mindfulness of the Buddha is a sudden escape from the three realms.
If you wish to quickly attain rebirth in the Pure Land by mindfulness of AmitÃ¢bha Buddha, you must accomplish the three karmas:
First, the mind has only faith;
Second, the mouth has only mindfulness;

Third, the body has only reverence. Whether there are people or not, whether one is noble or humble, old or young, day or night, always be diligent and respectful, and this is called accomplishing reverence.
Do not discuss the strengths and weaknesses of others, talk about food and treasures;
Only recite the Buddha with the mouth, with each sound uninterrupted, and this is called accomplishing mindfulness.

One should not fall into the afflictions of greed, hatred, etc., nor into disputes, beatings, scoldings, resentments, jealousies, killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, or lying, which are causes for falling into the three evil paths, because they are not in accord with the practice of mindfulness of the Buddha.

Only having faith in mindfulness of the Buddha, regardless of whether one is a monk or layperson, male or female, noble or humble, or whether one's offenses are light or heavy, faith is the fundamental basis.
If one achieves this, then even if one has myriad illnesses, they will all be cured without the need for worldly medicine;
myriad wholesome actions will naturally be accomplished without the need for worldly teachings or scriptures, and one will be able to achieve sudden enlightenment.
The accomplishment of myriad wholesome actions is not one's own ability, nor is it the power of practice.
According to the sutra text, it takes one great eon from the stage of ordinary beings to the first ground. If it is the power of the Three Jewels, then many eons are not necessary.
Moreover, according to the sutra text:

'I have heard that by speaking of Amitabha Buddha, even if one rejoices and leaps with joy for just a single thought or a single moment, and wholeheartedly dedicates the merit, one can attain rebirth and abide in the stage of non-retrogression.'
The Lotus Sutra says:
'The wise understand through parables.
In the world, only a mother's power can bring peace and comfort to her child;
in the world beyond, only the Buddhas can enable sentient beings to leave the sufferings of the three realms, be reborn in the Pure Land, see the Buddha, and hear the Dharma.'
Moreover, according to the sutra text, the Buddha has loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
Loving-kindness can bestow happiness, and compassion can alleviate suffering.
It does not matter if it is the suffering of hell, hungry ghosts, animals, or humans; if asked, it would not be called great loving-kindness and compassion.
Moreover, it is like a mother. In the world, a mother has various sufferings for her child, but she never complains of hardship or weariness, and takes joy as her foundation.
How could it be that the great sages, the Buddhas, with great compassion, do not ask about enemies, friends, monks, laypeople, men, or women, and equally save everyone universally?
What kind of suffering do they save and protect from?

The suffering of the world is a million times worse than the suffering of hell. The Buddhas immediately save from this. How much more so for the lightest suffering among humans? If they do not save, then it contradicts the sutra teachings.

The suffering of humans, if one generates the resolve to repent, performs various precepts and practices, and creates various merits, then all suffering is suddenly eliminated. Faith is initially accomplished, and one retreats from birth and death, fully knowing that one will not enter hell again.
The suffering of humans, the suffering is not immediately eliminated, and the illness is not immediately cured. Out of a thousand, there is not even one who believes.

Even if there are believers, it is no more than a few months, and they immediately fall back. They do not see the sutra text, because they do not know the suffering of the future. Their minds are unstable. The suffering of the present is also unable to be eliminated. Sentient beings slander and give rise to it.
Moreover, based on the sutra text, the present suffering is definitely extinguished, and future suffering will definitely not arise.

Now in the present world, there are those who recite the sutra, and there are those with different practices who correspond with the king, and their hair falls out, and the kasaya robe appears on their bodies, but they still have no precepts.
Within the world, from the king above to the parents below, they all pay respect in return. Whose power is this?
Isn't it the power of the Three Jewels?

Within the world, there are also those who, regardless of nobility or lowliness, male or female, are all made to be free, with clothing and food naturally provided, and those who see them pay respect without complaining of weariness.
For this reason, one should know that the power of the Three Jewels is only known by those who have faith;
Those without faith are like the blind and the deaf, no different.

Therefore, know that for those who think of the Buddha, with each sound unceasing, there is no illness that is not cured, no sin that is not extinguished, and they will definitely not be startled or afraid, nor will they turn back.

Day after day, the mind-eye will naturally open, and as one further focuses the mind, it will accord with the sutras and teachings. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, the mind will never be scattered, nor will one lose proper deportment.

Even if one hears various sutras and treatises, they will all accord with one's practice, and one will experience increasing joy. One will mutually guide those with faith, like a mother rescuing her child without tiring.
As for those without faith, it is better to remain silent and die than to speak and cause others to give rise to slander. This is not slandering others, but directly slandering the Buddha.

When expounding the AmitÄbha SÅ«tra, ÅšÄkyamuni expounds the Dharma that is difficult to understand for the sake of all beings. If there are those with faith, this is the Dharma that is extremely difficult to believe, known by the Buddhas of the six directions. Fearing that sentient beings in the future will give rise to doubt and slander, they therefore extend their tongues to bear witness, indicating that the text of this sÅ«tra is definitely not false.

Moreover, it is heard that in recent times, many practitioners have given rise to shock, doubt, and even slander. For this reason, the Buddhas repeatedly know that sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age do not have faith. If there are those who have faith, all the Buddhas will jointly protect and think of them.
If one does not have faith in the Buddha's words oneself, one cannot attain any goodness.
Abiding in the stage of nonretrogression is all the words of the AmitÄbha SÅ«tra.
If one does not cultivate practices oneself, one obstructs the holy path. Both this sÅ«tra and the teachings are spoken by the Buddha.

The teachings for one's own cultivation and the methods for the good spirits to protect and assist, if one deeply gives rise to faith and respect, practices without abandoning, the Buddhas will protect and assist.

Moreover, it is the teaching of the power of the original vows of the Buddhas. If one hears it in the present but does not have faith, one will directly enter hell without a chance of escape. Is this not a great mistake?

If one sees the text of this sutra, contemplates it again and again, and carefully examines whether there is a sutra teaching, only then can one begin to correspond with the practice of mindfulness of the Buddha, precepts, and the elimination of dharmas. However, if one can have deep faith and sincerity without retreating, with thoughts of mindfulness uninterrupted, calling out to the Buddha with every sound, regardless of whether one is a layperson or a monk, noble or humble, poor or rich, ugly or beautiful, male or female, with offenses either light or heavy, it is only necessary to achieve faithful understanding.
If one does not believe in the compassion of the buddhas, even if one's father and mother are present, there is no place to be saved and one cannot attain rebirth.
Only by achieving faithful understanding of the eternal abiding and non-extinction of the buddhas, and also being without retrogression,
can one have faith in the great sage Buddha, the most supreme, most excellent, and greatest of all sages and saints, who is called the World-Honored One.

Regardless of whether one is a sentient being of the past, future, or present, regardless of whether one's mind is large or small, good or evil, the Buddha knows the extent of it all.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

If there are people who believe in the Buddha's great kindness and great compassion, able to save sentient beings from the many evil karmic offenses and hindrances of the past, present, and future, and who repent with a sincere mind, the Buddha knows them all and immediately goes to save them, never missing the right time to deliver them. This is called great kindness and great compassion.
It is like a mother in the world who sees her child in filth and suffering from hunger and cold, and never leaves them. This is called a kind and compassionate mother.

The Buddha's great kindness and great compassion save hundreds of thousands of millions of times. Not only does he save from the suffering of the world, but also from the great suffering of birth and death.
Therefore, those in the world who are able to believe are saved, regardless of the heaviness or lightness of their offenses.
Respectfully following the text of the Lotus Sutra:
The Buddha said:

Moreover, regardless of whether one is a monk or layperson, male or female, noble or humble, old or young, beautiful or ugly, rich or poor, or the severity of one's offenses, for this reason, it only discusses those with faith who are able to repent, those with deep faith and accomplishment, and the uninterrupted recitation of the Buddha's name.

When this sutra was being spoken, the Buddhas of the six directions and Ganges sands all extended their tongues to bear witness. The Buddhas' compassion and equanimity universally save, regardless of whether one is a layperson or a monastic. Repenting, dedicating merit, and making vows, one definitely does not miss the time. This is called the Buddhas' impartial universal salvation of sentient beings.

If one's mindfulness is accomplished, no sin will not be eradicated, no illness will not be cured, no suffering will not be removed, no worry will not be dispelled. If there are people who, upon hearing, immediately repent, learn, practice, and contemplate the Buddha, this is the power of the Buddhas.
Only those who have faith will begin to realize:

First, in terms of physical actions, one should not kill, steal, or engage in sexual misconduct, nor should one beat or harm any sentient beings, nor should one touch worldly smooth and soft things such as beautiful flowers, silk, brocade, satin, or purple cloth, even if one encounters severe cold, one should die with the cold and never wear them again.

A woman wearing fine clothes, going out and about, fond of applying makeup, causing indulgence and many men to look at her frequently without letting go, her parents worry a lot and become angry, her brothers feel sad and become greatly angry, worldly people see her briefly and give rise to suspicion and slander, if teachers and monks see her, they will break the precepts, if thieves see her, they will give rise to thoughts of stealing - such hindrances are all the faults of fine clothes, which cannot be fully explained.

If one is filial, one will not wear fine clothes until death. Filial conduct is accomplished together. One's physical conduct is correct conduct. One does not neglect paying respects and praising. If discussing sleeping, one should not take off clothes, nor should one sleep on one's back with legs stretched out or speak. This is indulgence and laziness, except for the temporarily allowed times of old age, illness, and exhaustion.
One should be diligent and sleep late and rise early, like a strong person every day. The spirit and appearance change and become sharp, and wisdom increases day by day.
If one does not practice in this way, it is called indulgence and disbelief. Sins are not extinguished, and myriad affairs are not accomplished, let alone illness and suffering?
One also cannot be reborn.

Second, for the mouth, one should not drink alcohol, eat meat, the five pungent scallions, dregs, vinegar, yeast, flour, milk, cheese, butter, ghee, glutinous rice, or the best-tasting food in the world.
Even if encountering great hunger, one should rather endure hunger and die, and not eat again.

Killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, slander, angry speech, arrogant speech, domineering speech, resentful speech, doubtful and defamatory speech, acquisitive speech, divisive speech, flattery, disparaging and foolish speech, evil curses - such speech, if one wishes to speak, would be endless.
But hearing people's good and bad words, none should be spoken. This is endless and useless. Much contentious speech is attached to demons, and it also causes people to become ill.

If one does not speak again, it accords with the Buddha's teachings. One need not read scriptures, but only increase mindfulness of the Buddha, walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, unobstructed by livelihood. The sound of mindfulness of the Buddha is uninterrupted. Only urgently call out loudly, and again clearly pronounce the word. This teaching is like a child calling out to its mother, urgent and not to be scattered.
Go outside and remove evil conditions. This is a concentrated mind.
Meditation and mindfulness of the Buddha

Meditation and mindfulness of the Buddha are each with many approaches. Whether laypeople or monastics, as long as the mind is pure, it does not matter whether one is male or female, noble or humble. As long as one can have faith, respect, filial piety, and care for others, one can all eliminate illness and suffering and accomplish the Way.
For this reason, the Buddhas of the six directions manifest their broad and long tongues to testify to the truth.
It is also said:
Those who are able to have faith, be single-minded, and not abandon mindfulness are protected and cared for by all Buddhas.
This is the text of the AmitÄbha SÅ«tra, which is currently circulating and is not discontinued anywhere.

Third, for the mental actions, one should not covet or be deluded by improper means, should not give rise to doubts or slander, should not give rise to envy or resentment, should not give rise to the evil thoughts of killing, stealing, or sexual misconduct, should not give rise to arrogance, conceit, contempt for others, self-righteousness, or attachment to wealth and desires. Whether one is a monk or layperson, noble or humble, rich or poor, one should all be equal, not discriminating between enemies and friends, and in accord with the Buddha's teachings.

If one does not have such a mind, one should confess and repent, vowing to reform for the rest of one's life, neither changing in death nor in life. For such people, the moment they turn their thoughts towards the Buddha, they will immediately become aware, just as a child remembers his mother and cares for her without complaining of hardship or avoiding hard work, and immediately goes to see her.
If one can do so, then one's mind of great compassion will be pure, and equality will be like space.
The three karmas and six sense faculties should practice in accordance with the precepts and the Dharma in this way.

The unwholesome actions of the mind are greed, seeking profit like the ocean swallowing streams, and hatred, a fierce fire burning all merits. The disciple upholds this merit of contemplating the Buddha to repay the kindness of parents and creditors. May they accept this merit, and soon part from this world to be reborn together in the Pure Land. With utmost sincerity, I take refuge and bow my head to Amitabha Buddha.

Cultivating the West in the Twelve Hours Cultivating the West in the Twelve Hours At dawn, put on clothes, leave the house, and regulate the mind and spirit. Join palms, burn incense, and face the Land of Bliss. Earnestly pay homage from afar to the purple golden body.
At sunrise, one should not discuss the number of times of contemplating the Buddha, but should focus the mind on a single object. Do not be disturbed by false objects.

At mealtime, when thinking of the Buddha, one must first subdue self-importance. If one uses thinking of the Buddha to rely on self-importance, what beginning and what accomplishment is there in the cause of the Pure Land?
At noon, when advancing in the cultivation of the Pure Land, one must make a firm resolve. If one tastes the sweet nectar, one knows it is sweet oneself. Do not slander others and say it is not.
At noon, think of our teacher as if seeing him with one's own eyes. Boundless karmic hindrances will naturally be eliminated. Why bother to say it is useless hard work?
In the afternoon, in the midst of birth and death, one truly has reason to fear. If one does not take the swift gate of the Western Pure Land, one will sink and fall for dust-like kalpas.
In the evening, one must quickly uphold the cause of the Pure Land. If one is not diligent in thinking of the Buddha, then one day one will falsely make worldly dust.
At sunset, one should know that the light and scenery cannot last long. Before long, impermanence will come. Do not let the word Buddha leave one's mind and mouth.
At dusk, do not let the body and mind commit many offenses. Although the ten evil deeds lead to rebirth, how much better to quickly open the lotus of the upper grade.
At midnight, deeply contemplate the true samÄdhi of AmitÄbha. Even those on the high level of the ten grounds still cultivate it. If you do not believe, how can it not be a sin?
At midnight, day after day, contemplate AmitÄbha in this way. All will ride the lotus and be reborn. From now on, there will definitely be no birth and death.
At dawn, youth and vigor will suddenly turn to decay. Busily wandering through the cosmos, there is no one close. Only AmitÄbha alone welcomes us.

Text on Upholding Right Mindfulness at the Time of Death Text on Upholding Right Mindfulness at the Time of Death Zhigui Zi asked Chan Master Shandao:

Nothing is greater in worldly affairs than birth and death. If one does not breathe for a moment, one belongs to the next world. If one's thoughts err for a moment, one falls into the cycle of rebirth. This disciple has repeatedly received your guidance on the method of reciting the Buddha's name and being reborn in the Pure Land. The principle is very clear.

However, I am afraid that when sickness comes and death arrives, the mind and consciousness will be scattered, and I am also worried that others will disturb my right mindfulness and cause me to forget the pure causes.
I hope you will kindly point out the way to return to the right path, so that I may escape the suffering of sinking and drowning.
The master said:
Excellent question!
In general, when people are about to die and wish to be reborn in the Pure Land, they must not be afraid of death.

Always contemplate that this body is full of suffering, impure, and has all kinds of evil karma. If one can abandon this filthy form and be reborn in the Pure Land, experiencing immeasurable bliss and liberation from the suffering of birth and death, it is truly a matter of satisfaction, like taking off worn-out clothes and putting on precious garments.
One should simply let go of body and mind and not give rise to attachment.
Whenever one falls ill, one should contemplate impermanence and single-mindedly await death.
Instruct one's family members and caregivers, and those who come to inquire about one's condition:

'Anyone who comes before me, chant the Buddha's name for me, do not speak idle and trivial words, or talk about the affairs of the household, also do not need to comfort with soft words, or wish for peace and happiness, these are all empty and useless words.
If the illness is serious and nearing the end, relatives should not shed tears, cry, or make sounds of lamentation and distress, confusing the mind and losing right mindfulness.
Just chant the Buddha's name together, help them to be reborn, wait until the breath has ended for a long time, then it is acceptable to wail.
If there is even the slightest attachment to the worldly mind, it will become an obstruction and one will not be able to attain liberation.
If one can get someone who clearly understands the Pure Land to come frequently and encourage them, it will be a great blessing!
If one follows this, one will definitely transcend and be reborn, there is no doubt!'
He also asked:
Can one still seek medical treatment and take medicine?
He replied:
Seeking medical treatment and taking medicine are not mutually exclusive, but medicine can only cure illnesses, not life. If life is exhausted, what can medicine do?
If you kill living beings for medicine, it is absolutely not acceptable!
He asked again:
How about seeking blessings from the gods?
He replied:
The length of a person's life is already determined at birth. How can ghosts and spirits prolong it?
If you are deluded and believe in evil, kill living beings, and make sacrifices to ghosts and spirits, you will only increase your karmic offenses and shorten your life!
When the great life is exhausted, what can the minor ghosts do? You will only be in a panic, and neither will be of any help.
You should be very careful. You should copy this text and post it in front of you, so that you can see it from time to time and avoid forgetting it when in danger.
He asked again:
Can those who have never recited the Buddha's name in their lifetime still use it?
He replied:
This method, whether used by monks or laypeople, men or women, those who have not yet contemplated the Buddha, will all attain rebirth, without doubt!
I often see people in the world who recite the Buddha's name, pay homage, make praises, and vow to be reborn in the Western Pure Land in their ordinary lives.

But when they become ill, they are afraid of death and never mention the matter of being reborn and liberated. They wait until their breath is exhausted and their life ends, and their consciousness falls into the netherworld, and then they ring the bell for ten recitations.
It's like closing the door after the thief has left - what use is that?
The matter of death is serious, and one must rely on one's own strength.
If there is a single wrong thought, one will suffer for kalpas upon kalpas. Who can take one's place?ğŸ”½Think about it!

When there is nothing to do, one should diligently recite the Buddha's name with this method, and strive to uphold it. This is the great matter at the end of life.
It can be said to be a straight path to the West, a direct return home without asking for directions.
